sen.j: 那波加神社（なはかじんじゃ）は、滋賀県大津市にある神社である。
sen.e: Nahaka-jinja Shrine is in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Nahaka-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.
Nahaka-jinja Shrine is a Shinto shrine located in Otsu City, Shiga Prefecture.

sen.j: 式内社で、旧社格は県社。
sen.e: It is Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and its old classification of shrines has been prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka).
It is classified as a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and its old classification of shrines was prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka).
It is classified as a Shikinai-sha (shrine listed in Engishiki laws) and its old classification of shrines was prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka).
The enshrined deity
The enshrined deity
The enshrined deity

sen.j: 現在はフトダマが主祭神とされているが、明治時代まではウカノミタマが祭神と考えられていた。
sen.e: At present the Futodama is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities), however, until the Meiji Period Ukano-mitama had been considered the enshrined deity.
Although the Futodama is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities) at present, Ukano-mitama was considered as the enshrined deity until the Meiji Period.
Although the Futodama is the shusaijin (main enshrined deities) at present, Ukano-mitama was considered as the enshrined deity until the Meiji Period.

sen.j: 『侍選神名牒』では、「苗鹿」という社名から稲の神・宇賀御玉命が附会されたものであろうとしている。
sen.e: "侍選神名牒" assumes that the name of the shrine, "Nahaka", was associable with Ukanomitama no mikoto, the god of rice.
The "Tokusen Sinmyocho" (The commentary book of many shrines) assumes that the name of the shrine, 'Nahaka', was associable with Ukanomitama no mikoto, the god of rice.
sen.cmt: 『侍選神名牒』は『特選神名牒』（とくせんしんみょうちょう/-じんみょうちょう）の誤りではないかと思われます。" "を' 'に変更しました。
sen.e: The "Tokusen Sinmyocho" (The commentary book of many shrines) assumes that the name of the shrine, 'Nahaka', was associable with Ukanomitama no mikoto, the god of rice.

sen.j: 三十番神の第29番「苗鹿大明神」（本地仏 阿弥陀如来）は当社祭神のことである。
sen.e: The "Nahaka Daimyojin" (honji-butsu (original Buddhist divinity) is Amida Nyorai (Amitabha Tathagata)), the twenty-ninth god of Sanjuban shin, means the enshrined deity of this shrine.
The 'Nahaka Daimyojin' (honji-butsu [original Buddhist divinity] is Amida Nyorai [Amitabha Tathagata]), the twenty-ninth god of Sanjuban shin, means the enshrined deity of this shrine.
The 'Nahaka Daimyojin' (honji-butsu [original Buddhist divinity] is Amida Nyorai [Amitabha Tathagata]), the twenty-ninth god of Sanjuban shin, means the enshrined deity of this shrine.

sen.j: 相殿に小槻氏の始祖である於知別命を祀る（一説には雄琴神社 (大津市)祭神・今雄宿禰）。
sen.e: Ochiwake no mikoto, the earliest ancestor of the Ozuki clan is enshrined together (in the other opinion, Imaonosukune, the enshrined deity of Ogoto-jinja Shrine of Otsu city).
Ochiwake no mikoto, the earliest ancestor of the Ozuki clan is enshrined together (in the other opinion, Imaonosukune, the enshrined deity of Ogoto-jinja Shrine of Otsu city).
Ochiwake no mikoto, the earliest ancestor of the Ozuki clan is enshrined together (in the other opinion, Imaonosukune, the enshrined deity of Ogoto-jinja Shrine of Otsu city).

sen.j: 末社として祭神の荒魂を祀る那波加荒魂神社がある。
sen.e: Nahaka-aramitami-jinja Shrine which enshrines Aramitama as an enshrined deity is its Massha (small shrine belonging to the main shrine).
Nahaka-aramitama-jinja Shrine which enshrines Aramitama as an enshrined deity is its Massha (small shrine belonging to the main shrine).
sen.cmt: 「那波加荒魂神社」 の読み方は「なはかあらみたまじんじゃ」です。
sen.e: Nahaka-aramitama-jinja Shrine which enshrines Aramitama as an enshrined deity is its Massha (small shrine belonging to the main shrine).

sen.j: 現在は本社・末社という関係になっているが、かつては那波加神社が下宮、荒魂社が上宮であった。
sen.e: At present, the relationship between the Nahaka-jinja Shrine and the Nahaka-aramitami-jinja is Honsha (the main shrine) and Massha, however, it used to be the lower shrine for the Nahaka-jinja Shrine and the upper shrine for the Nahaka-aramitami-jinja.

Although the relationship between the Nahaka-jinja Shrine and the Nahaka-aramitami-jinja is Honsha (the main shrine) and Massha (the subordinate shrine) at present, the Nahaka-jinja Shrine used to be the lower shrine and the Nahaka-aramitami-jinja used to be the upper shrine.

Although the relationship between the Nahaka-jinja Shrine and the Nahaka-aramitami-jinja is Honsha (the main shrine) and Massha (the subordinate shrine) at present, the Nahaka-jinja Shrine used to be the lower shrine and the Nahaka-aramitami-jinja used to be the upper shrine.
History
History
History

sen.j: 社伝によれば、祭神・天太玉命は太古よりこの地に鎮座していた。
sen.e: According to the shrine's biography, the Ame no Futotama no Mikoto (one of the gods in Japanese mythology), the enshrined deity, had been enshrined in this place since time immemorial.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: According to the shrine's biography, Ame no Futotama no Mikoto (one of the gods in Japanese mythology), the enshrined deity, had been enshrined in this place since time immemorial.
sen.cmt: 天太玉命のtheを削除しました。
sen.e: According to the shrine's biography, Ame no Futotama no Mikoto (one of the gods in Japanese mythology), the enshrined deity, had been enshrined in this place since time immemorial.

sen.j: その際、天大玉命の農事を助けるために鹿が現れ、稲の苗を背負って運んだので「なはか（苗鹿）」という社名・地名になったという。
sen.e: Then, a deer appeared to help agricultural affairs of Ame no Futotama no Mikoto and carried rice plants, and that is the origin of the shrine's name as well as place name of "Nahaka" which literally means rice plant and a deer.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処"which"以下に、原文にはありませんでしたが、「苗鹿」の説明を付け加えました。
sen.e: Then, a deer appeared to help agricultural affairs of Ame no Futotama no Mikoto and carried rice plants, and that is the origin of the shrine's name as well as the place name of 'Nahaka' which literally means rice plant and a deer.
sen.cmt: place nameにtheを追加しました。" "を' 'に変更しました。
sen.e: Then, a deer appeared to help agricultural affairs of Ame no Futotama no Mikoto and carried rice plants, and that is the origin of the shrine's name as well as the place name of 'Nahaka' which literally means rice plant and a deer.

sen.j: 天智天皇7年（632年）に社殿造営、大同 (日本)2年（807年）に荒魂社が造営されたと伝えられる。
sen.e: It has been said that a sanctuary was constructed in 632 and Aratamasha in 807.
It is said that a sanctuary was constructed in 632 and Aratamasha in 807.
sen.cmt: has been saidをｉs saidに変更しました。
sen.e: It is said that a sanctuary was constructed in 632 and Aratamasha in 807.

sen.j: 仁寿元年（851年）、小槻宿禰今雄が雄琴荘を拝領して以降、当社と雄琴神社と氏神とし、氏寺として建立した法光寺が当社別当寺となった。
sen.e: Since Ogotoso was given to 小槻宿禰今雄 in 851, Hoko-ji Temple, which was constructed as Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory), regarding this shrine and Ogoto-jinja Shrine as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion), became the Betto-ji Temple (a temple attached to a shrine) for this temple.

Since Ogotoso was given to Ozuki Imao no Sukune in 851, Hoko-ji Temple, which was constructed as Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory), regarding this shrine and Ogoto-jinja Shrine as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion), became the Betto-ji Temple (a temple attached to a shrine) for this temple.
sen.cmt: 「小槻宿禰今雄」→「小槻今雄宿禰」（おづきいまおのすくね）
sen.e: Since Ogotoso was given to Ozuki Imao no Sukune in 851, Hoko-ji Temple, which was constructed as Uji-dera Temple (temple built for praying clan's glory), regarding this shrine and Ogoto-jinja Shrine as ujigami (a guardian god or spirit of a particular place in the Shinto religion), became the Betto-ji Temple (a temple attached to a shrine) for this temple.

sen.j: 延喜式神名帳では小社に列格している。
sen.e: Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) lists this shrine as Shikinai-shosha.
Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) lists this shrine as Shikinai-shosha.
Engishiki jimmyocho (a register of shrines in Japan) lists this shrine as Shikinai-shosha.

sen.j: 明治9年10月に村社に列格し、明治28年1月に郷社に、明治35年5月に県社に昇格した。
sen.e: It promoted to sonsha (a village shrine) in October 1876, gosha (village shrine) in January 1895, and prefectural shrine (of prefectures other than Kyoto and Osaka) in May 1902.
It promoted to a village shrine in October 1876, a regional shrine in January 1895, and a prefectural shrine in May 1902.
sen.cmt: 括弧内の説明を残した訳に書き換えました。郷社をa regional shrineに変更しました。原文にない訳が含まれていたため削除しました。
sen.e: It promoted to a village shrine in October 1876, a regional shrine in January 1895, and a prefectural shrine in May 1902.
